Qst.askee: Minister for Community, Rural and Gaeltacht Affairs
Qst.Quest: the extent to which his Department will support local community groups on a countrywide basis as was done previously by the Department of Social and Family Affairs; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Community, Rural and Gaeltacht Affairs (Mr. N. Ahern)
Speaker.P: I understand the Deputy is referring to the scheme of grants to voluntary and community organisations which has in recent years been administered by the Department of Social and Family Affairs.

My Department has taken responsibility this year for the operation of this scheme which provides once-off grants to voluntary and community groups that focus on tackling poverty and disadvantage and enhancing community development.

My Department is examining administration issues in the operation of the scheme this year and I expect to be in a position soon to announce details of the scheme for 2003, which will be advertised in both the national and provincial press. As has been the case in previous years, applications will be accepted from groups countrywide and I expect that the qualification criteria will be broadly similar to those applicable previously.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Departmental Expenditure.

Qst.askee: Minister for Community, Rural and Gaeltacht Affairs
Qst.Quest: the various headings under which expenditure has occurred in his Department since he took office; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Éamon Ó Cuív Éamon Ó Cuív
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Community, Rural and Gaeltacht Affairs (Éamon Ó Cuív)
Speaker.P: Since the establishment of my Department in 2002, our programme expenditure has been concentrated under the broad headings of “An Ghaeilge agus An Ghaeltacht”, “Community Affairs”, and “Rural Affairs”, as indicated in the revised Estimates volume for 2003, which was published recently.

Under “An Ghaeilge agus an Ghaeltacht”, expenditure is focused on An Foras Teanga, the North-South language body, the operation of various schemes within the Gaeltacht, the provision of support to Údarás na Gaeltachta and Ciste na Gaeilge, as well as funding towards the improvement of the infrastructure and facilities on inhabited offshore islands.

Expenditure under the heading “Community Affairs” covers the community development support programmes, various local development and voluntary initiatives, the national drugs strategy, the Programme for Peace and Reconciliation, youth services and facilities, and Waterways Ireland, the North-South waterways body.

MainHeading.P: As regards “Rural Affairs”, my Department allocates funding to the Western Development Commission and Western Investment Fund, together with various rural development schemes, including the area-based rural development initiative, Leader+, INTERREG, the peace programme and CLÁR.
The current and capital spend from 1 January to 20 March 2003 across my Department's Vote was €37.69 million.

P.i: Questions Nos. 222 and 223 answered with Question No. 149.

Qst.askee: Minister for Community, Rural and Gaeltacht Affairs
Qst.Quest: the number of applications on a county basis received to date for grant aid in respect of grants administered by his Department; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Éamon Ó Cuív Éamon Ó Cuív
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Community, Rural and Gaeltacht Affairs (Éamon Ó Cuív)
Speaker.P: My Department funds a wide range of grant schemes across the range of its remit. Many of these are administered on behalf of the Department by subsidiary agencies such as ADM and local Leader groups. My Department is not in a position to provide the Deputy with the information requested in respect of applications received by such bodies.

In the case of many of the schemes for which application is made directly to the Department, especially those relating to Gaeltacht areas, applications are not generally classified on a county by county basis and the information requested by the Deputy is not readily available. Given the wide range of such schemes and the large volumes of applications received thereunder on an ongoing basis, I am satisfied that the work involved in compiling and collating a county by county breakdown of applications received would exceed the information value of such statistics.

However, I have directed that the Deputy be supplied with the requested information in respect of all schemes administered directly by my Department for which such information can be readily compiled. If the Deputy wishes to contact me with a specific query in respect of any scheme under the remit of my Department, I would be happy to assist him.

P.i: Questions Nos. 225 and 226 answered with Question No. 149.

Qst.askee: Minister for Community, Rural and Gaeltacht Affairs
Qst.Quest: if further funding can be provided to a group (details supplied).

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Community, Rural and Gaeltacht Affairs (Mr. N. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The young people's facilities and services fund, YPFSF, was established in 1998 as part of the Government's overall strategy to tackle drug misuse. The fund aims to assist in the development of youth facilities, including sport and recreational facilities, and services in disadvantaged areas where a significant drug problem exists or has the potential to develop.

The national assessment committee, NAC, of the YPFSF, which is chaired by my Department, is examining the services projects funded under round one of the fund. The intention would be that, where they are found to be effective, they will be mainstreamed by enabling their ongoing provision by statutory agencies.

Qualification for continued funding will be dependent on the successful evaluation of each project by the services steering group, which has been set up to examine the projects, and sufficient funding being in place. The work of the steering group should be completed over the coming weeks with a view to the NAC making recommendations to the Cabinet committee on social inclusion shortly thereafter.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: if a person who is a proprietary director of a company but is paid under the PAYE/PRSI system on a weekly basis as a wage earner can qualify for family income sup plement; if this person and their partner have four children, the maximum amount they can be eligible for; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social and Family Affairs (Mary Coughlan)
Speaker.P: Family income supplement, FIS, is designed to provide cash support for employees on low earnings with families and thereby preserve the incentive to remain in employment in circumstances where the employee might only be marginally better off than if he or she were claiming other social welfare payments.

Proprietary directors employed in an executive role in a company under a contract of service and paying PRSI class A may have entitlement to FIS depending on their salary. However, directors employed in an executive role under a contract for service and paying PRSI class S are not covered for FIS as they are not regarded as employees. Directors who receive fees in respect of their office pay PRSI class S on the fees and would not have entitlement to FIS. Where clarification is required with regard to a person's employment status, this is obtained by the deciding officer prior to reaching a decision on the FIS application.
The maximum weekly amount of FIS payable to a person in low-paid employment with a dependent spouse or partner and four children is €109.
